text: RewriteMap is not permitted in a .htaccess file. I presume there are good reasons for this. However, it would be amazingly convenient if it were permitted. Can we consider the implications of doing so, and, if it's not terrible, permit it, perhaps with an associated configuration directive for the server administrator to enable/disable this feature?
creator: rbowen@apache.org

text: My gut reaction is a resounding WONTFIX: rewritemap is only implemented to run early, and running it in a directory context would be rather a lot more work.  And since rewritemap may run nonstandard code (including in-process code), there are big security issues to consider if it's permitted to .htaccess users.
creator: nick@webthing.com
rbowen@apache.org
text: Yeah, I rather expected that response, and I don't entirely disagree. I wonder if a subset of RewriteMap - like only txt: or perhaps txt:, dbm: and rnd: - could be an acceptable compromise. Of course, that would no doubt be more difficult to do.
This isn't going to happen. Withdrawing request.
creator: rbowen@apache.org
